I can understand deleting Uber for the anti-unionization (in-fact, that's why I did), but that's about it for me really. The whole being on Trump's advisory board thing is silly, it's not at all telling of their position on a lot of Trump's policies, especially when you consider Tesla (Tesla!) are also advisories. If anything, you need people who disagree with Trump on his advisory board so we don't have an echo chamber government. Heck, WWF and Greenpeace should do the same thing, I find it really sad that there isn't more diversity on advisory boards. At this point, it's not clear where they stand.
I also think it's a tad rich that Lyft is safe because they donated $1m to ACLU but did the same shady shit as Uber at JFK and that was what got everyone pissed off with Uber. Uber is at least allocating $3m to provide legal services to their employees. Now I'm not defending Uber - I believe that complete deregulation is a laugh and everyone should be given worker's compensation and sick leave. But this fiasco with Uber just feels strange. Why is no one calling for a boycott of Tesla?
This was the screen-test before the finale.

A lot of Uber drivers are pay-check to pay-check people and I am sure they would like to protest, but also need to put food on the table. I don't think it is taking advantage of the situation - people need to get home, that includes the sick, injured and elderly. You won't be making a statement by denying them a service - honestly if Uber did not still service the area, the headlines would be about the mayhem at JFK since no one can go home and how dare the taxi industry protest.
I'm a nurse. We have protests too, but we can't all go on protests and not every hospital should or can go to a protest. There are people who rely on you at the end of the day. I mean I agree that Uber should join the protest, heck I think everyone should, but this idea that everyone should halt everything and ignore their wider responsibilities is a bit of a stretch

I'm unsure how what Uber did is a bad thing? I'm sure their workers can refuse if they please, even so, some people need to get home and if the regular taxis are striking, well it just makes sense Uber will pick up the slack?
I completely understand the protesting over the ugly orange dick, but are people deleting the app over people doing their jobs? I mean Uber is not obligated to join the protest, but they still are a taxi company

Homophobia? Sure, maybe in the much older demographic. Racism? Sure, predominantly if you're middle eastern or sikh because ignorant people think a turban means you're a member of ISIS. This however, really depends on where you live and who you associate with. In Sydney, it's more the wealthier north shore and eastern suburbs area which have less diversity to begin with which are mostly racist, but inner and western Sydney is such a mix of a variety of cultures and ethnicities it's more on the level of racial microaggressions. It's incredibly diverse and openly so - a lot of Australians take pride in the nation's multiculturalism, despite what the attitudes on the media perpetuate.
Cost of living. Um. Yeah no, lol. Most apartments will cost you $500 p/week without bills, which is around half of the average person's weekly income. Wages and welfare are out of proportion with the cost of living and work, at least in Sydney, is a fight to the death to find. A lot of that has to do with industry closing and moving off-shore and government dislike of innovation, and because an entry-level position requires that you work in the industry for 2 years previously, but they all say that...

Honestly couldn't care less about whether a guy wants to wear makeup. There is a world of difference between doing some minor editing like bronzing, lip-balm and even a tinted moisturiser and concealer to say, drag makeup and epic contouring.
I use a tinted moisturiser daily as my sunscreen during summer. My skin always goes pink when it's a hot day so it keeps that at bay and I use concealer under my eyes after I've worked night-shifts consistently and need to not look dead during the day. I also use a lipbalm - non-tinted because if it moisturises me, I don't need the colour.
As long as it's not cakey or obvious, I don't think any guys would care. Make up is a personal choice and we all have perfectly valid reasons to use or not use it.

My step sister is the same with pregnancy tests and she has that implant in her arm which prevents her from getting pregnant. It's more effective than getting Fallopian tubes tied, but she would do a pregnancy test every month. Some people just need that level of reassurance, and that is fine. But after about the 6th month she stopped doing because she got the reassurance she needed. Same can be said for you, the more you test, the more you are to feel safe and eventually the anxiety you feel will fade. It is however recommended to test at least once or twice a year.

Sure do! This is my grandma's recipe:
* 2 cups of plain flour * 5 bananas (4 if brown or over-ripened) * 1 cup of brown sugar (3/4 cups if using over-ripened bananas) * 1/2 cup of butter (softened - leave sitting in room temperature for 10 mins, or just put it in the microwave for a few seconds until soft) * 2 eggs * 1 teaspoon of baking soda * splash of vanilla essence (I normally add 1 teaspoon) * pinch of salt
Combine the butter with the sugar then add the eggs. Beat well. Add bananas - really mash them in. You can use a potato masher if you wish. Add flour in gradually (1/3 at a time) - sifted so you don't get lumps, then add salt, baking soda and vanilla. Combine well and pour it into a well-oiled baking tin at 355 F (180 C) for about 50 minutes - 1hr. Take out. Let it cool. And enjoy :)
Completely optional, but you can glaze it with jam (I recommend apricot jam). Just warm the jam in the microwave and paint it on the cooled banana bread.
